text: good morning today is Friday February
3rd I'm Corva Coleman from NPR news and
here are today's top stories China says
it's examining reports that a
surveillance balloon is flying over the
continental United States Pentagon
spokesman Brigadier General Pat Ryder
says the flying orb is not a danger it's
currently traveling at an altitude well
above commercial air traffic and does
not present a military or physical
threat to people on the ground instances
of this kind of balloon activity have
been observed previously over the past
several years a senior defense official
says the Pentagon has been tracking the
balloon for a few days and has high
confidence that it came from China
National Security officials debated
whether to shoot it down but they
decided against it they say it does not
appear to pose a security threat and
cannot collect information beyond what
could be gathered by a satellite
forecasters say a blast of Arctic air is
Sweeping in over parts of the Northeast
dangerously cold winds are expected to
spark wind chills far below zero Mount
Washington in New Hampshire's White
Mountains is home to what's considered
the worst weather in the world and this
weekend won't be an exception from
Member station WBUR Samantha kuzia has
more temperatures could get as low as 50
degrees below zero on the summit setting
a new record with wind chill forecasters
say it will feel anywhere between 100
and 110 degrees below zero Francis
terrazowitz is a meteorologist at the
Mount Washington Observatory Exposed
Skin will become frosted in less than a
minute and then even on the warmer end
of things say if the winds were closer
to 80 miles per hour and the lows only
got down to 30 degrees below zero
frostbite would be expected within five
minutes or so the White Mountains are a
popular tourist destination but
terrazowitz says this isn't the weekend
to be heading up there for NPR news I'm
Samantha coetzia President Biden has
been traveling up and down the East
Coast this week to discuss projects
funded by the bipartisan infrastructure
law and his administration NPR's Barbara
sprunt reports today he'll visit
Philadelphia to announce major funding
for water upgrades President Biden and
vice president Harris will visit the
Belmont water treatment plant and
announce 500 million dollars to upgrade
Philadelphia's water facilities and
replace nearly 20 miles of lead service
lines it's part of a broader goal to
replace all lead service lines in the
country within the next decade 160
million dollars of the investment will
come through the bipartisan
infrastructure law which Biden signed in
2021 the rest comes via a loan from the
Environmental Protection Agency Biden
made similar visits to Baltimore and New
York earlier this week to announce other
major Investments part of a Victory lap
he's taking for steering Federal funding
to infrastructure projects Barbara spren
and Pure News Philadelphia while he's in
Philadelphia today Biden will also
attend a meeting of the Democratic
National Committee State lawmakers in
Utah have introduced a range of bills
this week that are intended to save the
Great Salt Lake from drying up and Piers
Kirk Siegler reports scientists warn
that climate change and Rapid population
growth could lead to the Lake's demise
within five years a bipartisan group of
legislators is floating upwards of a
half billion dollars in spending
including measures that would encourage
Farmers to conserve more water and
expansions of lawn removal programs in
cities State House minority leader
Angelo Romero represents neighborhoods
in Salt Lake City's West Valley by the
receding Lake I hope we're not looking
at five years because I'm just really
worried about what that means for the
future of Utah but also the future of
the neighborhoods and the health of the
people who live in the neighborhoods
that I represent scientists are warning
that wind storms off a dried up lake bed
would kick up toxic dust the saline Lake
contains high levels of mercury and
other toxins Kirk Ziggler NPR news
there's a new report from the Department
of Education it finds that federal
covid-19 emergency funds helped millions
of college students stay in school
during the pandemic and Pierre's janaki
metha reports physical classrooms might
have been empty for much of the pandemic
but new data show that in the first two
years of the Biden Administration
emergency federal funds helped keep
about 18 million college students in
school in 2021 40 billion federal
dollars went to higher education and it
was students at under-resourced
institutions that received the largest
amount of Aid nearly 80 percent of
students at historically black colleges
and universities got federal aid along
with the 6 million community college
students less than 10 percent of the
emergency funds are left institutions
have until June 30th to spend it janaki
metha NPR news
this is NPR
